text: 'Sup, you beautiful bastards, hope you're having a
fantastic Friday. Welcome back to the
Friday show. If you're new here, Monday
through Thursday I like to talk about the
world, the news, all the good stuff, and
then Friday I like to have a
conversation with you guys and reply to
your comments. That said, something I want
to hit on before we jump into it. This
week, a ton of people asked me to cover
as a story or just comment on the Laci
Green 'red pill' situation. One, for those
who don't know, Laci Green is a noted
feminist, social justice warrior. We've been
friendly and then not so friendly in the
past. In the past when I covered news about
her, she said I was trying to push some
sort of narrative. In the past she has said,
"Could @PhillyD be any more of a drama queen?
I'm sick of alt-right assholes using my
face to make money and direct harassment
at me. f**k off." Also back then, she said my
coverage of a story around her was to
promote the narrative that feminists are about censorship.
I don't think that this issue
is really about, you know, copyright
and fair use. I think that Philip
DeFranco and other people who made
videos about me, attacking me on this the
past few days are really seeing this as
an opportunity to go in on the narrative
that feminists are out to censor people.
I'm gonna leave that there because i could do a
whole video on toxic feminism versus
classical feminism. After all of that, she
really didn't post for a while until
recently she put out a video called
Taking the Red Pill. In it, she talks about
taking a look at herself opening herself
up to conversations with people she
would never spend time with in the past.
People with completely different
opinions, anti-feminists, having a dialogue,
and so people asked, "What do you think
about this?" To that I say if it's genuine,
whether it be Laci or anyone else, if
they open themselves up to a dialogue,
They open themselves up to what is hopefully
a healthy conversation, I say good. That
goes for the people on both sides of
every issue you have to just be open
there are some people that are so in
their bullshit they don't see any way
except theirs. Fantastic example of it:
Tariq Nasheed, on Twitter.
Everything's about race, everything is
racism. This week there was this
conversation that stemmed from an
interview with Bill Cosby and there were
a lot of people saying that this was racism.
Cosby is being accused by all these women because of racism.
To which others contested, the number of black
women that also accused Cosby, which
Tariq said, "For your information, just
because they sprinkled a couple of black
Bill Cosby accusers in with dozens of
white ones, doesn't negate the fact that
it racism." and I-, I couldn't help myself.
Guys, I love conversation, I'm not perfect
I, I asked him, "Is it exhausting being
that stupid or do you just get used to
it after a while?"
I'm not proud of it, then he hit me with a
"Que the white supremacist -" Did you spell cue wrong?
"Cue the white supremacist with multiple
troll accounts making the usual goofball
insults hashtag yawn. Okay, to Tariq and
anyone else that has this mindset, not
even just about this issue, if you
automatically think anyone making fun of
what they think is a stupid comment or
any criticism whatsoever, is a person
who is a white supremacist or the worst of
the worst, you need to take a moment look at
the criticism to see if there's
something valid. 'Haters gonna hate and
you can't sweat them,' yes, but also every
criticism against you is not hate. The moment
you cross that line and you think that's the
truth, then you've just put yourself in a
little bubble. But that's where I'm going
to end that one, and into the Monday show!
Monday, we talk about the Fyre Festival
Fiasco, WannaCry Ransomware, malware

the Crow: "That's exactly why the

Trust us," No, I've been hurt too many

But it's the problem that it represents
and also the people that were hit. The

The digital equivalent of someone walking

Ty G wrote, "Comedy has no 'line' to cross.
Nothing is off-limits and it's supposed
to be that way. I'd rather it be illegal to
be offended than to have to go to court
for joking." Okay I was--, I was with
you, and then you completely lost me. I mean I
personally believe that there is a line
in comedy, and that's actually where a
lot of the comedy comes from. Getting
close to it, kind of going over it,
pushing it. There's also styles of comedy, like
Anthony Jeselnik that are, that the whole
point is: we're over this line, it's crazy
how fucking far past this line we are,
and that's where we're going to live for
an hour. And that line has continued to
move all these years. I think the big
thing is that we don't try and ruin
someone just because they crossed it in
a way that didn't work. Comics, whether
successful or just someone trying to be
a comic in general, I think that they
have to have some some level of a safety net.
Where if they swing and miss on a joke,
they're not automatically out, and then
kicked off the team, and then ejected
from the stadium. And as far as the making it
illegal to be offended, I mean that, that's insanity.
Becca G wrote, "I'm Jewish and had family in the Holocaust.
I'm honestly not sure how I feel about it. Is it
